title: Abortion decriminalised in NSW after marathon debate
text:
Applause in parliament on Thursday after contentious bill cleared its final hurdle, following weeks of protest

NSW parliament has passed laws decriminalising abortion, more than a century after it was included in the state’s criminal code.

There was applause in the lower house on Thursday as the Abortion Law Reform Act 2019 passed its final hurdle following a marathon debate and weeks of protest.

It comes after the bill passed the upper house 26 votes to 14 on Wednesday night following nearly 40 hours of discussion - making it the third longest debate in the state’s house of review.

Scott Morrison targeted in anonymous leaflets over NSW abortion bill Read more

More than 100 amendments were discussed, with the private member’s bill to return to the lower house on Thursday before it becomes law.

The bill, presented to parliament in August by the independent MP Alex Greenwich, takes abortion out of the criminal code.

“With the passage of this bill abortion will be decriminalised in NSW – I am sorry that has taken us so long,” Greenwich said on Wednesday night.

The bill also allows terminations up to 22 weeks as well as later abortions if two doctors agree.

Upper house MPs on Wednesday night passed an amendment that recognised doctors performing abortions after 22 weeks can seek advice from a multidisciplinary team on a hospital advisory committee.

The Labor MP Penny Sharpe, who is one of 15 co-sponsors of the bill, on Wednesday night said the vote had been 119 years in the making.

NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian: leadership spill called off by anti-abortion MPs Read more

The draft legislation has been opposed by religious groups, anti-abortion activists and several MPs who raised concerns about late-term and sex-selective abortions, conscientious objection and the way the bill was introduced.

Tensions reached a climax last week when the Liberal MPs Tanya Davies, Matthew Mason-Cox and Lou Amato said they would move a leadership spill motion against the premier, Gladys Berejiklian, over her handling of the bill.

The rebel MPs, who ultimately withdrew the motion, said it had been made clear to the premier that “at an absolute minimum” four key amendments were required to the bill to ensure their continued Liberal party membership.

The amendments included a ban on sex-selective abortions and stricter regulation of late-term abortions.

Mason-Cox said there had been “significant improvement” to the bill through amendments but he declared it “dangerous”.

Amendments passed in the upper house include one clarifying that doctors must provide appropriate care to babies born alive after a termination.

Another states that the NSW parliament opposes sex-selective abortions, and a future report on the issue is to include prevention recommendations.
